page.title: 09WATER PROBLEMS cont.
page.content: On the flat valley floor of the Howe of Fife there is sometimes too much water. Rossie Loch, which once covered a large part of the area, was drained in 1723. In 1805/1806 a more succesful attempt at draining the land was acheived by cutting ditches to the River Eden. The newly drained land was used as summer grazing meadows. The land dried out and became ideal for arable farming, although some areas require a lot of draining and have been left as pasture land. Recently a Govt. grant was obtained to install new drains. An artesian basin lies underneath this area and has been exploited by local farmers. Boreholes have been drilled and water successfully tapped. This has been a great asset but the basin ends close to the foot of the hill, where there is a fault line.
